results.notes:
Cortinarius multiformis (Fr.) Fr. Cortinariaceae, Agaricales. (Паутинник изменчивый).
Cap: 3-6cm wide, blunt gentle cone-shaped dull pinkish-yellow or light cream-yellow when young, then light brownish-yellow convex with broad indistinct knob. Cap surface is smooth.
Gills: attached, sometimes with pinching out end, long gills broad or moderately broad, intermediate gills are medium, short and very short length; color from light cream up to dull brownish-pink.
Stalk: 3-7cm long, whitish and silky up to somewhat fibrous; 0.6-1cm thick, hollow when old.
Veil: (?) It disappears very fast (?).
Odor is unpleasant and somewhat bad soap.
Habitat: small groups scattered in pine-tree forest with some birches and aspen
Edibility: no data.
Season: May – July (?)
results.location_name: Karkaraly National Park, Karaganda District, Kazakhstan

results.notes: A pair fruiting in grass under a mature, planted spruce in landscaped area next to church parking lot. It was sunset when I found these so the in situ photo (last) is a result of insufficient light. Had to use a flash for a couple of the pics as I rapidly lost all light. Other photos were taken the next morning after specimens spent the night in the refrigerator=) Large cap: 16 cm. (used string for close approximation due to the upturned condition of the cap). Stipe: 16.4 cm. X 2.3 cm. Smaller cap: 9 cm., covered with white, cottony warts; stipe 9.3 cm X 1.2 cm, essentially equal with enlarged base and skirt-like ring, shaggy with concentric bands at top of base.
results.location_name: West St. Louis Co., Missouri, USA

results.notes:
Found one group, on a rotten hardwood log by Rapidan Camp Trail.

Flesh and gills tough for a Mycena. No obvious odor (didn’t crush or taste them).

Basidia ~20+4 x 4, four- and two-spored. Spores 7×3, or (mostly) smaller. Cheilocystidia densely packed on the gill edge, hard to separate, 20-30 × 5-9. Pleurocystidia not immediately observed. Pileipellis hirsute, most cells smooth, but divierticulate ones was easy to find too.

results.notes:
Entoloma strictius group, Entolomataceae, Agaricales
Cap: 2-5 cm wide, gentle wide cone with indistinct knob up to almost flatten with a small blunt knob; brownish-pink or dull brownish-orange; surface smooth and radial lined out of knob. Flesh is light pinkish. Odour is weak mealy or common mushroom aroma.
Gills: almost free or free, light pink up to dull brownish-orange, moderately broad with short and very short additional gills.
Stalk: 3.5-7 cm long, 0.3-0.7cm thick, fibrous and hollow, dull brownish-orange.
Edibility: no data
Habitat: very rare kind; scattered small groups on intensive rotten wood in pine-tree forest with some birches
Season: May-June

results.notes: One of the rare species in my observations. I only found it once living on stones close to the sea border. At the time the lirellae were similar to other species in the genus Opegrapha. This time the lirellae were overmature and seem to have desintregrated living exposed some white material (pruina?). Most of the spores over overmature but some young ones also exist. A characteristic feature of the spores is the existence of pointing ends, very pronounced at one of them; The overmature spores, many shrived inside the asci, are dark brown and ornamented, being highly rugose.

results.notes:
Growing on the thick bark of an old Quercus suber.
This is my first observation of this species, though I must have observed it in the past. In fact, if one compare the photos of this observation with those of observation 178147 one can see that they are identical. Moreover, the photos were taken at the same group of trees!
The reason discovered in the British Flora as follows, quoting from P.A. Wolseley:
“Often grows with, and apt to be confused with Arhonia pruinata which, however, has C+red apotheciod pruina.”
In spite of that macro similarity the micro features are really different, starting with the apothecial section and ending in the asci and spores. Please, have a look and compare.
Let me say that the dimensions given for the spores are not very accurate, for being difficult to measured halonate spores with a thin halo. Nevertheless these values fall within those given in The British Flora for Lecanographa lyncea.
The septation of the spore is variable from 5 to 8 septa (while the British Flora gives 7-8 septa).
It should also be noted that the IKI reaction seems weird, maybe because I used a more concentrated lugol than usual; according to the British Flora there should have been a K/I+ dark blue reaction in the ring zone at the apex, which is a feature of the genus Lecanographa and not only of this particular species.
Beyond L. lyncea the British Flora only mentions one more species of Lecanographa growing on bark – L. amylacea- with 3-4 septate and shorter spores.

results.notes:
This young specimen does not show the prominent reticulation generally seen on most of the B. brunneus stipe. But zooming in on the third posted photo, reticulations are seen on the upper portion of the stipe.

Bluing reaction weak for B. brunneus.

Macrochemical tests match the NAB/BRB profile for brunneus:
KOH: amber on cap surface; orange becoming muddy orange on pores; blue flash on stipe followed by saffron-yellow; orange-brown on stipe context.
Ammonia: mahogany on cap surface; pale orange on pores; negative on context.

Dominant tree type birch. Also present was oak, ash, one sapling hemlock, mountain laurel.

I’ll preserve half of this specimen. (Other half doused with chemicals.)

Many examples of B. brunneus found in previous years in this location.

Found shortly after significant rainfall.

results.notes:
On sandstone rock in full sun in grassy openings with surrounding oak woodlands.

Chalky white thallus with round somewhat flat-topped apothecia, mostly contiguous, not effigurate, lacking prothallus, K-. Apothecia <1 mm with black disk and raised margin. Epihymenium greenish, turning brownish in K. Need to do Iodine test for blue hymenium, will update.

Asci clavate, spores immature, appeared to be in the 2-6 per ascus category as opposed to 8, but at first glance I thought it was an Acarospora type thing with many ascospores. Still not sure how to interpret all the material in the asci that is smaller than the obvious globose ascospores. Pyncnidia not observed.

results.notes:
This is similar 182205
Cap: 2-4cm, semispherical or convex with deep sunken centre then wide convex up to almost flat, sometimes with wavy margin; color is dull orange up to light reddish-brown. Cap surface is smooth and some radial wrinkled or radial lined; flesh is thin and yellowish or pinkish-white. Fertile surface looks as branched gills: narrow thick-edged ridges forked and rare cross-veined with tiny additional transversal gills distant and descending stalk, yellowish-white or dull yellow.
Stalk: 4-7cm long, 0.3-0.6cm thick and hollow, enlarged up to a cap and change into a cap sometimes dividing into main branches; brownish-yellow up to orange-brown.
Edibility: no data, but odor is pleasant.
Habitat: rare kind, small group or single crowded clusters on partially rotten stumps in pine-tree forest with rare birches.
May – July.

results.notes:
The field trip of last weekend had a genus as target: Rinodina!
I take this observation to give some notes about the results obtained in this genus and will update it in the future as far as the things become more clear. Of course, many other material except Rinodina was observed and will be considered at different observations.
The main reason for the target genus was that during some years of observations at this locations I didn’t identified a single specimen of Rinodina and recently some came to light. The purpose was to see if at some of the places there was abundant material.
As far as I can say now and even before starting the always time consuming microscopic analysis, the result was far beyond my most optimistic expectations. Furthermore, by the lack of time and opportunity didn´t revisited the place where recently I found my only specimen of Rinodina capensis. Summarizing:
- Many specimens of Rinodina aspersa were found at several different places (see from observation 241354 to observation 241356); My conclusion is that it is a widespread species at this location;
- Many specimens in the group of R. atrocinerea and R. beccariana were found in several different places; these two species are similar and have similar spore-types, differing in the chemistry that sometimes is not sufficiently clear (see from observation 241357 to observation 241360); My conclusion is that this group of species is also widespread at this location;
- After a previous homework I conclude that the specimens consider at this observation, which were collected at the same place than that in observation 203982, must belong to the species R. sophodes;
- A new specimen growing parasitic on Miriquidica deusta was collected; this is most probably a new species (see observation 241361).
Of course all that is to be confirmed or not with the corresponding microscopy, which I intend to do in the forthcoming weeks.

Regarding this observation the fact that lead me to the name of Rinodina sophodes was that these specimens were collected at the same tree than the one in observation 203982, a young chestnut, and the microscopy of that one reveals spores of Milvina-type, which are characteristic of that species, growing on bark. The thalli are so small that without knowing what to look for most probably they would remain invisible. Consequently, I could not find them anywhere else. I hope that my future microscopic analysis will permit to confirm this suspection. Because the thalli are minuscule I present the specimens observed in two sets of 5 specimens each.

[Microscopy to come]
results.location_name: Serra de São Mamede, Portugal

results.notes:
See the notes of observation 241353.
Only very recently (April 2016) I could identify this Rinodina species growing on rock, at observation 236229; More recently I observed it and posted at observation 236293 and at observation 238337. So the question appears: is it common? The answer is yes! It is very widespread at this location and this time I present three more observations of it, this one and two other in the sequel.

As already mentioned at a former observation previously this species was considered as a variety of R. aspersa, sharing with it many features including the chemistry. However, the C+ red reaction that is usually clear in R. aspersa sometimes is dubious in R. atrocinerea leading to a possible confusion with R. beccariana , which reacts C- and as similar spores of the so-called Pachysporaria-type.
In the case of this observation the C+ red reaction was well visible.

results.notes:
Hi guys,

I have lots of potting sitting in small mason jars and I was planning to plant some vegetables in it. However, last couple weeks, I have noticed some jars have yellow and green mold/fungi growing. Also, some jars have yellow mushrooms popped out. I have seen mushrooms growing out of the soil with the plants growing there, but this was my first time seeing mushroom growing with the unvegetative soil. The cap has been on with two tiny holes on it. I was wondering if anyone can help me identify those creatures and offer me some solutions to further prevent this from happening. I am thinking about mixing in some type of fungicide such as copper sulfate and sulfur. I have tried with cinnamon but the mushrooms and mold are still growing.
Thank you very much!

results.notes: Has a turd-looking peridium resembling the picture of Alpova trappei on pg. 12 of “Field Guide to North American Truffles”. Yellow droplets rested on the exterior, making this truffle appear like a shiny, infected turd. This fungus was accidentally discovered when I lifted up a large concrete block resting on forest soil. The truffle was found 4.5 inches deep in the humus. Owing to its uninviting appearance, I was at first hesitant to touch it. Lifting up the side I discovered threadlike hyphae connecting it To the substrate. The Gleba is occasionally knobby to the touch. the gleba is very firm yet squishy. Marbled Gleba smelling like paint and Rhizipogon, the odor causing a slight tingling sensation in the sinuses. If one runs the gleba, the pad of your finger is left covered with a Black smeared sludge resembling to a lesser extent, shaggy mane (Coprinus comatus) “ink”. The understory where it was found was devoid of shrubs and Forbes. Neighboring tree species included Larix occidentalis, Pinus monticola, Betula papyrifera, Pseudotsuga menziesii, Pinus ponderosa, and Thuja plicata.

results.notes:
On Caloplaca arenaria, apothecia (observation 230817).

The perethecia (apparently actually “pseudothecia”) appear as black dots on the apothecia of Caloplaca. In section, the perethecia are immersed in the apothecia tissue, forming a globose structure. The perethecial wall is thin, hyaline below with a thick blue-black layer at the top, kind of like an involucrellum in Verrucaria.

Spores are distinctive with a single septum dividing a much reduced, attenuated, slightly curved lower cell from a more normal looking ellipsoid upper cell. Unfortunately I don’t have measurements, I put my microscope on a different computer and the software has to be calibrated again, and my calibration slide is not with me.

results.notes:
On sandstone boulders in semi-arid grassland setting, along a seasonal creek.

Thallus epilithic, tan (same color as substrate), areolate, rimose. Apothecia biatorine (margin not carbonized and lacking algae), black but turning reddish brown when wet, originating within the areoles, occasionally dividing, epruinose to sparsely pruinose, often with whitish thallus material clinging to outer margin. Epihymenium red-brown, hymenium hyaline but dingy, exciple black, K-, with red-brown coloration on interior side adjacent to hymenium.

Asci clavate, spores many per ascus, tiny, single-celled, hyaline, narrowly ellipsoid.

I’m going “promising” with this one, with the caveat that this genus is understudied and difficult. The main key to this determination is the distinct presence of an epilithic thallus, whereas most other species usually are endolithic or chasmolithic and therefore not visible.

Also of note, this could be a compilation of two taxa, one with tan thallus and epruinose apothecia, and one with white thallus and pruinose apothecia (see photos). There are some thallii and apothecia that are dying, maybe something is killing portions of it and making it look different. Micro was the same for both.

results.notes:
This specimen is on crumbling Monterey shale bedrock sheets in chaparral with Manzanita (the rare Arctostaphylos pilosula).

Thallus 6.5 cm diameter, adnate, yellow-green to blueish green, older thallus with a distinct goldish pruina. Lobe tips black, shiny, typically about 1.5mm wide. Thallus underside pale brown with simple, black rhizines, common but not dense. This thallii is sterile, lacking apothecia, soredia and isidia. Pycnidia are abundant, appearing as tiny black dots on thallus.

Spot tests: Thallus barely K+Y, P+O (faint), Medulla K+Y turning red, P+O.
